summary: This is a court opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the defense's motion to exclude the government's expert witness, Dr. Lisa Rocchio, in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The court largely denies the motion, allowing Dr. Rocchio to testify about grooming, trauma, and victim behavior in child sexual abuse cases, but excludes one specific opinion about 'grooming-by-proxy'.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, accused of conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein and participating in the sexual abuse of minors.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case who authored this opinion and order on the admissibility of expert testimony.

persons.name: Lisa Rocchio
persons.context: Clinical psychologist proposed by the government as an expert to testify about grooming, trauma, and victim behavior in child sexual abuse cases.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the predator with whom Maxwell allegedly conspired to groom and sexually abuse minors.

connections.description: The government alleges Maxwell conspired with Epstein, a predator who groomed and sexually abused minors.
Rocchio is an expert witness for the prosecution against Maxwell; Maxwell's defense moved to exclude her testimony.

events.title: Daubert Hearing
events.description: Court conducted a hearing to examine the admissibility of Dr. Lisa Rocchio's expert testimony, during which both parties examined her.

events.title: Court Issues Opinion on Expert Testimony
events.description: Judge Nathan issued this opinion and order, largely denying the defense's motion to exclude Dr. Rocchio's testimony but excluding one specific opinion.

keyFacts: The court ruled that Dr. Lisa Rocchio, an expert on child sexual abuse trauma and grooming, is qualified and her testimony is largely admissible in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

The court excluded one specific opinion from Dr. Rocchio: that the presence of a third party can facilitate grooming (termed 'grooming-by-proxy'), finding it lacked sufficient support in academic literature.

Dr. Rocchio's admissible opinions include: how grooming works without physical force, why victims may not immediately disclose abuse, long-term psychological consequences of abuse, and why disclosure may be delayed or incremental.

The defense argued Rocchio's methods were unreliable because they were based on patient reports and lacked an error rate, but the court found these objections misplaced in the field of clinical psychology studying sexual abuse.
The government alleges Ghislaine Maxwell both participated in sexual abuse of minors and conspired with Jeffrey Epstein, who groomed and abused minors.
